questions.question: What term is used to describe the capacity of some erythrocytes to vary in size, especially in relationship to some anemias?
questions.rationale: Additional descriptors of erythrocytes associated with some anemias include anisocytosis (assuming various sizes) and poikilocytosis (assuming various shapes). The remaining terms are not associated with this condition.

questions.question: What is the fundamental physiologic manifestation of anemia?
questions.rationale: The fundamental physiologic manifestation of anemia is a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, resulting in tissue hypoxia.

questions.question: The paresthesia that occurs with vitamin B12 deficiency anemia is a result of which of the following?
options: Reduction in acetylcholine receptors in the postsynaptic nerves
Myelin degeneration in the spinal cord
Destruction of myelin in peripheral nerves
Altered function of neurons in the parietal lobe
questions.rationale: Effects on the nervous system can occur if a vitamin B12 deficiency causes the anemia. Myelin degeneration may occur with the resultant loss of fibers in the spinal cord, producing paresthesia (numbness), gait disturbances, spasticity, and reflex abnormalities.

questions.question: Which of the following describes how the body compensates for anemia?
options: Increasing rate and depth of breathing
Hemoglobin holding more firmly onto oxygen
questions.rationale: Tissue hypoxia creates additional demands and compensatory actions on the pulmonary and hematologic systems. The rate and depth of breathing increase in an attempt to increase the availability of oxygen.

questions.question: Which is the most common type of anemia?
questions.rationale: Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia worldwide.

questions.question: Which blood disorder is an X-linked recessive disorder?
questions.rationale: Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive clotting disorder.

questions.question: What is the cause of beta-thalassemia major?
questions.rationale: Beta-thalassemia major results from absent beta chains, leading to absence of hemoglobin A.

questions.question: Which condition is associated with decreased platelet count in children?
questions.rationale: ITP is an autoimmune condition leading to destruction of platelets.

questions.question: Which clinical manifestation is typical of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)?
questions.rationale: Children with ALL often present with bone pain, fever, and general malaise.

questions.question: Which diagnostic finding is consistent with thalassemia major?
questions.rationale: The absence of hemoglobin A is diagnostic of thalassemia major.

questions.question: Which condition is the most common of the childhood cancers?
questions.rationale: Leukemia is the most common malignancy of childhood, accounting for about 30% of all cancers in children.

questions.question: Which type of leukemia is most common in children?
questions.rationale: ALL is the most common type of childhood leukemia.

questions.question: Which condition results in sickling of red blood cells?
questions.rationale: Sickle cell disease is characterized by the production of abnormal hemoglobin S, which causes red blood cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions.

questions.question: Which clinical manifestation is most consistent with hemophilia?
questions.rationale: Hemarthrosis (bleeding into the joints) is characteristic of hemophilia.

questions.question: Which diagnostic test confirms iron deficiency anemia in children?
questions.rationale: Low serum ferritin is diagnostic of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.question: Which genetic disorder is characterized by a defect in the production of clotting factor VIII?
questions.rationale: Hemophilia A results from a deficiency in clotting factor VIII.

questions.question: Which disorder is characterized by excessive red cell destruction?
questions.rationale: Hemolytic anemia results from premature destruction of red cells.

questions.question: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with pernicious anemia?
questions.rationale: Pernicious anemia results from a deficiency in vitamin B12.

questions.question: Which population is most at risk for iron deficiency anemia?
questions.rationale: Children and women are at highest risk.

questions.question: Which condition is associated with abnormal hemoglobin synthesis and ineffective erythropoiesis?
questions.rationale: Thalassemia involves defective hemoglobin synthesis and ineffective erythropoiesis.

questions.question: Which deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia?
questions.rationale: Both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies impair DNA synthesis, resulting in megaloblastic anemia.

questions.question: Which anemia is caused by bone marrow failure?
questions.rationale: Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure, leading to pancytopenia.

questions.question: Which anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic red cells?
questions.rationale: Iron deficiency anemia produces microcytic, hypochromic red cells.

questions.question: Which is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.rationale: Von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

questions.question: Which is the most common nutritional disorder in the world?
questions.rationale: Iron deficiency anemia is the most common nutritional disorder worldwide.

questions.question: Which test is used to diagnose sickle cell disease?
questions.rationale: Hemoglobin electrophoresis identifies hemoglobin S in sickle cell disease.

questions.question: Which condition is characterized by excessive iron absorption and deposition?
questions.rationale: Hemochromatosis involves excessive absorption of dietary iron and deposition in tissues.

questions.question: Which laboratory finding is characteristic of iron deficiency anemia?
questions.rationale: Low serum ferritin is characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.question: Which anemia is associated with a deficiency in folic acid?
questions.rationale: Folate deficiency produces megaloblastic anemia.

questions.question: Which symptom is common in children with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.rationale: Children with iron deficiency anemia often develop pica (craving non-food substances).

questions.question: Which conditions are inherited as autosomal recessive disorders? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Both sickle cell disease and thalassemia are inherited as autosomal recessive disorders.

questions.question: Which are clinical manifestations of sickle cell disease? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Sickle cell disease presents with vaso-occlusive, sequestration, aplastic, and hyperhemolytic crises. Hemarthrosis is characteristic of hemophilia, not sickle cell disease.

questions.question: Which laboratory findings are associated with pernicious anemia? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Vitamin B12 deficiency produces macrocytosis, hypersegmented neutrophils, and low reticulocyte counts. Serum ferritin is decreased only in iron deficiency anemia.

questions.question: Which conditions may present with thrombocytopenia? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: All listed except hemophilia A (which is a clotting factor deficiency).

questions.question: Matching: Match the anemia with its cause: Iron deficiency anemia, Pernicious anemia, Aplastic anemia, Hemolytic anemia, Sickle cell anemia
options: Caused by impaired hemoglobin synthesis due to lack of iron
Caused by premature destruction of red blood cells
questions.rationale: 35. Caused by vitamin B12 deficiency → Pernicious anemia; 36. Caused by impaired hemoglobin synthesis due to lack of iron → Iron deficiency anemia; 37. Caused by bone marrow failure → Aplastic anemia; 38. Caused by abnormal hemoglobin S → Sickle cell anemia; 39. Caused by premature destruction of red blood cells → Hemolytic anemia.
